awd_titl_txt: CNH: Coupled Natural and Human Ecosystems over Long Periods: Pueblo Ecodynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project expands the temporal and spatial dimensions of prior research to examine the interaction of social and natural factors that shaped the pre-historic agricultural societies of Pueblo Indians in the Mesa Verde and Rio Grande regions of the southwest United States.  This project will conduct a coupled socio-natural science analysis of one of the most dramatic migration episodes in world prehistory; model the evolution of incipient market-based economies from earlier economies of reciprocity, a major economic transformation of global interest; and compare land-use strategies and outcomes for people of a single cultural tradition in two different, sequentially occupied environments. The project will collect new information on known archaeological sites, and conduct a study of resource availability and use to model the evolution of economic strategies among households and larger groups.  Model simulations will be used to explore processes leading to group-formation. This includes identifying communities in the archaeological record, evolving them in simulation models, and allowing them to compete and cooperate with other groups. 

This work contributes to understanding several near-universal processes in societies undergoing population growth and economic intensification following the development of new technologies.  Equally important is the enhanced understanding it will provide of the rich archaeological records of Mesa Verde and Rio Grande regions, which together are visited by close to a million people each year.  The research team is highly interdisciplinary and includes archaeologists, a geochemist, a computer scientist, an ecologist/geographer, a specialist in ancient DNA, and an economist.  Researchers from the two national parks, the Santa Fe National Forest, and major museums are an integral part of the team.  Collaborating institutions will involve undergraduate and graduate students and the public in research activities.  Results will be disseminated to school-age children and the general public through interpreters at the parks, through the educational activities of Crow Canyon Archaeological Center, and through exhibits and other interpretive materials developed for museums and units of the National Park Service and US Forest Service.

The Village Ecodynamics Project (VEP) investigated the relationship between Pueblo societies and their envionments in the period from AD 600-1600 in Southwest Colorado and northern New Mexico (Figure 1). The research area in Southwest Colorado is within the Central Mesa Verde (CMV) region and includes Mesa Verde National Park and Canyons of the Ancients National Monument. Farmers left this area, as well as the larger Four Corners region, in the mid-to-late AD 1200s; this area would not be farmed again until the arrival of Euro-American farmers in the late AD 1800s. The New Mexico study area is within the northern Rio Grande (NRG) region and includes Bandelier National Monument, portions of Santa Fe National Forest, Los Alamos National Laboratory, and lands belonging to Ohkay Owingeh (San Juan), Santa Clara, San Ildefonso, Pojoaque, Nambe, and Tesuque pueblos. These areas were first occupied by farmers in the AD 800s or 900s, and grew rapidly in population in the AD 1200s. The first substantial Spanish expedition to enter what is now the southwestern United States spent the winters of 1540 and 1541 just south of this area, near present Albuquerque.

The VEP developed new techniques to estimate where precipitation and temperature in any year would allow corn (maize) to be grown without irrigation (Figure 2). We also developed new techniques for estimating human population size through time from site information (Figure 3). Finally, we used existing techniques to estimate levels of violence through time in our two research areas (Figure 4), and to estimate birth rates (Figure 5) and life expectancy (Figure 6) from 1100 BC to AD 1600 for the entire Southwest. We found that populations were probably growing most rapidly throughout the Southwest from AD 500 to 1000, and that the mid-AD-1100s drought was severe enough to decrease both life expectancy and birth rates. In the CMV, population growth was positively correlated with increases in maize niche size and also with regional birth rate. Levels of violence were generally higher in the CMV than in the NRG, and were particularly high in periods when the per-capita maize niche size was low and variable. Political events also played a role in levels of violence, since the appearance of Chacoan influence from the San Juan Basin to the south in the late-AD 1000s, and the demise of Chaco in the mid-AD 1100s, also marked violent times in the CMV. Simulation and scaling studies suggest that exchange, violence, and slight positive returns to sociality all contributed to aggregation (village formation) in the CMV. Simulation suggests that increases in polity size in the CMV involved conflict over agricultural land as populations grew.

The depopulation of the area including the CMV in the AD 1200s was due to several factors. The maize dry-farming niche was relatively larger in the NRG than in the CMV for much of the AD 1200s (Figure 2), creating a pull to the south. Very dense populations of farmers in the CMV depleted deer, the largest game animal, and as a result became dependent on domesticated turkey (fed maize) for much of their protein. In conjunction with a diet that contained up to 80% maize, this created dangerous dependency on a single crop. Waves of immigrant farmers entered the CMV in the early-to-mid 1200s and settled in areas prone to drought, likely adding to the violence that again became prominent in this area in the late 1200s. Other factors such as long-term declines in temperature and summer precipitation, and depredations by the earliest nomadic hunters from the north (possibly ancestors of the Navajo and Apache) may also have contributed to the final depopulation, but were not systematically assessed by this project.
